content.text: Your body has limits. How much you can carry is determined by Chrome — your physical augmentation and raw body power.

The difference matters. A Chrome 4 contractor carries their weapons, armor, and maybe a med kit. A Chrome 10 contractor carries all that plus a teammate's spare ammo, a full harvest load, and the salvage nobody else could lift. A Chrome 15 augmented brute hauls equipment that would normally require a vehicle.
Every item has a Weight value measured in units. Negligible items (coins, keys, ammo for a crossbow) have weight 0 — they don't count unless you're carrying absurd quantities.
If you exceed your Carry Capacity:

• 1-5 units over: -1 to all physical checks. Speed reduced by 1 range band per round of movement. • 6-10 units over: -2 to all physical checks. Speed reduced by 2 range bands. Cannot dodge (Evasion halved, round down). • 11+ over: Cannot move faster than Adjacent. Cannot dodge. Cannot attack. You're a turtle with debt.
This is where the Chrome vs brains split matters.

Chrome determines how much you carry out. High Chrome contractors can haul more raw material from a harvest site. Each point of Carry Capacity above your equipped gear's weight contributes to your Available Harvest Carry — the space you have left for loot.

Interface and Edge determine how well you harvest. The harvesting check (see Harvesting & Crafting) uses relevant skills to determine the quality and value of what you extract. A high-Interface contractor with a steady hand and rift knowledge carves out the valuable organs, the rare crystal cores, the intact spell glands. A high-Edge contractor spots the thing everyone else missed — the hidden cache, the rare material, the component that's worth ten times the obvious stuff.

The result: the Chrome 8 brute carries out a backpack full of generic rift meat. The Interface 6 channeler carries out three perfectly extracted spell glands worth more than the entire backpack. Both are correct. Both are needed. The ideal team has both.
Available Harvest Carry = Carry Capacity - Equipped Gear Weight
Each unit of Available Harvest Carry lets you bring back 1 harvest unit from a mission. Harvest units are then valued based on your harvesting check results.
Augments are your primary progression system. Each augment has a purchase cost (the augment itself) plus an installation cost (someone has to put it in you). Both come out of your pocket.
Augment prices by tier (ranges from the Augment Trees):

rows: Entry-level mods. Basic implants. Your body's first real changes.
Serious augmentation. Your body is adapting to significant modification.
Advanced systems. Multiple integrated modifications working together.
High-end hardware. Your body is more machine/magic than stock at this point.
Passive bonus. No purchase needed — your body has fully integrated the tree.

content.text: Total cost to reach Mastery in one tree (10 augments):
You need 10 augments to unlock T5 Mastery. Assuming a mix of tiers:

• 3× T1 (~600 cr) + 3× T2 (~1,200 cr) + 2× T3 (~1,200 cr) + 2× T4 (~1,900 cr) = ~4,900 cr in augments alone • Installation (Licensed Clinic): 10 × 250 cr = 2,500 cr • Installation (Team Chrome Tech): Free • Total with clinic: ~7,400 cr. Total with Chrome Tech: ~4,900 cr.
That's roughly 10-15 missions worth of saving at early-game pay rates. Mastering a tree is a campaign-long investment. Having a Chrome Tech on the team saves you almost half the cost.
Every augment purchase is a trade-off against every other use of money:

• That 400 cr T2 augment is also 13 days of Apartment rent
• That 950 cr T4 augment is also 6 Scar treatments at a Street Doc
• That 250 cr installer fee is also 5 encounters of Magi Sniper ammo
Contractors who rush augments go hungry. Contractors who never augment fall behind. The sweet spot is somewhere in between, and finding it is half the game.
When an installation complication occurs (see Services below), the augment still installs but malfunctions:

rows: Intermittent. Augment works 50% of the time (flip a coin each encounter). Repair cost: 50 cr.
Painful. Augment works but causes -1 to all checks for 24 hours post-installation. No repair needed, just time.
Rejection Risk. Augment works but your body fights it. Take 1d4 damage (unresistable) and +2 Toxicity. If not treated within 48 hours, augment must be removed and reinstalled.

content.text: Not everything is a thing you carry. Some costs are services rendered.

rows: Cheap installer. Roll 1d6 after installation: on a 1, complication (augment malfunctions until repaired, 50 cr).
Professional job. No complication risk for T1-T2 augments. T3+: roll 1d6, complication on a 1.
Top-tier installation. No complication risk at any tier. Logged on your medical record — the corp knows what you have installed.
A teammate with Tech T2+ can install augments. No fee. Complication risk same as Street Doc for T3+, none for T1-T2. The value of having a Chrome Tech on the team.
Remove 1 Scar. Roll 1d6: on a 1, gain a different debuff.
Remove 1 Scar. Clean. Logged on your record.
Remove 2 Scars. Illegal. If caught, you're "product."
Full Scar reset. Debt contract — they own a piece of you.
Clear 2d6 Toxicity. 1 AP. DC 7 complication check.
Clear 4d6 Toxicity. Extremely illegal. 1d20 vs DC 5: fail = lose 1d4 HP permanently.
Answer one question about local contracts, factions, or threats. Quality varies.
Detailed intel on a specific target, location, or contract. Reliable.
Add one conditional modifier to a weapon. Requires Tech T2+ or a weaponsmith NPC.
Fake identity that passes casual scanner checks. Premium forgeries (1,500 cr) pass corporate-grade checks.
Your scanner reads 10 lower than actual for 48 hours. Illegal.

content.text: New contractors receive their Kit's starting gear plus 100 credits (modified by Kit — Negotiator gets +100 cr, some Kits get +0). This is your first and last handout.

• Med Patches (25 cr each) — always carry at least 2
• Ammo for your ranged weapon (50 cr) — if applicable
• Breather Mask (100 cr) — if heading into a rift immediately
• Save the rest — you'll need it for rent
After Session 1, every credit comes from contracts. Budget accordingly.

"Equipment is provided at the contractor's expense. Equipment damaged during contracted operations may be eligible for partial reimbursement pending review of the incident report, damage assessment, contractor conduct evaluation, and prevailing corporate policy. Average review period: 8-14 business weeks. Average approval rate: 6%. Carry a spare."
"The weapon you buy is the weapon everyone has. The weapon you modify is the weapon nobody expects. And the weapon a real crafter builds? That's the weapon that comes home when you don't."

Stock gear keeps you alive. Modified gear keeps you alive better. Every mod is a tactical choice — not a flat power increase, but a trade-off that shifts how a weapon or piece of armor performs. A scope makes your rifle deadlier at range but doesn't help in melee. A quick-release mag lets you reload for free once, but it doesn't add damage. Living armor hurts anything that grabs you, but you can never take it off.

Mods are the gear layer of the customization stack: Kit Abilities define how you fight. Augments define what your body can do. Mods define what your equipment can do. All three feed the same character identity — and all three cost credits.
Every piece of gear has a mod slot count based on its complexity and size. You can only install mods up to your slot limit.

rows: Light melee (Combat Knife, Gauntlets, Ripper Claws)

content.text: Every mod has a type that determines who can install it and whether it can be removed.

rows: Yes — 1 downtime activity, mod recovered intact
Bolted, screwed, mounted. Sights, grips, stocks, plates. Physical attachments.
Coatings, infusions, acid treatments, material bonding. Changes the gear's composition.
No — permanent, living organism bonded to gear
Living materials grafted onto equipment. Symbiotic organisms, rift-grown tissue, reactive membranes.
Rift energy bound into the gear's structure. Volatile. Adds Toxicity costs.
Swap during downtime, old mod deactivated (not destroyed)
Electronic/neural interfaces that connect gear to the user's augments.

content.text: Mechanical mods are the bread and butter. Anyone with Tech T2 can install them. They can be removed and reused. Swapping a scope takes a downtime activity.

Chemical, Biological, and Rift mods are permanent. Once applied, they're part of the gear forever. If you want a different one, you need a new weapon. This is intentional — these mods change what the gear is, not what's attached to it.
Neural mods split the difference. They're electronic, so they can be swapped, but they require specialized knowledge to install and the old mod goes dormant (not destroyed) when replaced.

rows: Mod not installed, no damage. Retry costs another downtime activity.
Mechanical: no damage. Chemical: mod consumed, must buy another.
Crafting check DC 7-9 depending on type
Chemical/Bio/Rift: mod consumed on failure. Biological: 10% chance of hostile reaction (1d6 damage to gear).
Costs 50% of mod price as installation fee. Available in most cities.

content.text: Professional Shops exist for crews without a crafter. The 50% installation fee is the price of convenience — and another reason having a crafter on the crew saves money.

rows: 1 downtime activity. Mod recovered intact. Can be reinstalled.
Cannot be removed without destroying the mod AND dealing 1d6 damage to the gear (reduced armor/accuracy).
Cannot be removed. Attempting to remove deals 2d6 Toxicity to the remover.
1 downtime activity. Old mod goes dormant. Can be reactivated later if reinstalled.
+1 accuracy at Close range. No benefit at Medium+.
Overwatch costs weapon AP (removes the +1 AP tax).
+1 damage per die at Medium+ range. -1 accuracy at Close.
+1 accuracy at Close. -1 damage per die at Medium+. Removes Heavy tag (can be dual-wielded as Medium).
First reload per encounter is free (0 AP).
Attacks from Hidden don't automatically reveal your position. Stealth check (DC 8) to remain hidden after firing.
+1 damage on Shove attempts. Shove knocks target 2 range bands instead of 1 on success.
-1 AP cost (minimum 2). The weapon swings faster.
Crits apply Bleed 2 in addition to normal crit effects.
+1 Evasion while this weapon is equipped. Defensive crossguard.
Weapon can make melee attacks: d8 accuracy (Chrome), 1d6 damage, 1 AP. Not good. But better than nothing when they close the distance.
Removes the -2 accuracy penalty for moving (Sniper Rifle, Heavy Crossbow).
First attack each encounter costs 1 less AP (minimum 1). Fast draw.
Weapon returns after throw. No retrieval needed.
Attacks apply +1 Poison stack on hit. Lasts for full encounter, reapply between missions (50 cr materials).
Attacks apply Corrode 1 on hit (reduce target armor by 1, stacks). Permanent weapon treatment.
On hit, target's next movement costs +1 AP. Single-target Slow.
On crit, target is Blinded for 1 round (-4 accuracy, -2 Evasion). Powder reservoir refills between missions (25 cr).
+1 Penetration (ignores 1 additional Armor per die). Permanent. Reduces weapon resale value by 50%.
Weapon becomes immune to Corrode and environmental degradation from rift dimensions. Permanent.
All standard Charges from this weapon apply Burning on hit (1d4 damage/turn, 1 AP to extinguish). Permanent barrel treatment.
Weapon bonds to your hand. Cannot be disarmed. +1 accuracy when below 50% HP (the weapon senses your adrenaline).
On hit, apply +2 Poison stacks (instead of +1 from Venom Coating). Self-replenishing — no reapplication cost.
Once per encounter, fire a spore cloud instead of normal attack: all enemies in Close range of impact point gain +2 Toxicity. No accuracy roll. Area effect.
Weapon adjusts to your grip in real-time. +1 accuracy on all attacks. The organism is learning how you fight.
Blade is replaced with self-sharpening rift-grown bone. +2 damage per die. Weapon repairs itself between missions (self-healing — never needs maintenance).
On hit, heal 1 HP. Stacks with Siphon Strike if you have it. The weapon drinks.
Penetration 2. The blade exists partially in another dimension. +1 Toxicity per encounter used.
Attacks ignore cover bonuses. The round phases through obstacles. +1 Toxicity per encounter used.
Once per encounter, your attack hits twice (roll damage twice, apply armor to each separately). The echo strikes from a dimensional fold. +2 Toxicity when used.
On crit, target makes a Grit check (DC 8) or ages rapidly — all their physical stats drop by 1 for the rest of the encounter. +1 Toxicity per encounter.
On hit, target cannot move away from the point of impact for 1 round. Dimensional anchor pins them. +1 Toxicity per use.
When you use Mark Target or Analyze Weakness on an enemy, you get +2 accuracy (instead of +1) against that target with this weapon. Requires neural jack augment.
Your Opportunity Attacks with this weapon use weapon damage dice instead of the standard 1d6. Your reflexes and the weapon are one system. Requires neural jack.
+1 accuracy against targets that moved this round. The weapon calculates trajectory. Requires neural jack.
After hitting with this weapon, your next attack with a different weapon this turn gets +1 accuracy. Dual-wield optimization. Requires neural jack.
At the start of combat, this weapon identifies the highest-threat enemy (most HP or highest damage output). You get +1 accuracy against that target for the entire encounter. Requires neural jack.
+1 Armor. Adds +1 Weight. Simple but effective.
-1 Weight (minimum 0). Evasion cap increased by 1 (if applicable).
Two items can be magnetically attached to armor (accessible as Quick Action). Weapons, tools, medkits.
Mount one consumable (Med Patch, Combat Stim, Scrubber). When you drop below 25% HP, it auto-activates for free. One-shot — must reload between encounters.
Reduce falling damage by 1d6. Reduce Shove/knockback distance by 1 range band. Absorbs blunt force.
Swap Weapon costs 0 AP (Quick Action). One weapon stored internally.
Immune to airborne Toxicity and inhaled poisons. Doesn't protect against contact or injected Toxicity.
+2 to Escape Grapple checks. Exterior surface is slick and contoured for escaping holds.
First hit per encounter deals 0 damage (armor absorbs the full impact). Layer must be repaired between encounters (50 cr materials).
Immune to Corrode condition. Rift Goblin spit, Static Hunter disruptors — none of it degrades your armor.
Immune to Burning condition from environmental sources. Still vulnerable to direct weapon-applied Burning.
+1 Evasion vs ranged attacks. Surface deflects targeting systems.
-1 Toxicity gained per encounter (stacks with Rift-Walker Suit). Permanent treatment.
+1 Armor vs critical hits specifically. Reinforced at stress points.
Anything that Grapples you takes 1d6 damage per turn (the armor bites back). Additionally, the armor slowly repairs itself — recovers 1 Armor point per day if damaged by Corrode.
When hit by a melee attack, attacker makes Grit check (DC 6) or gains +1 Toxicity. Passive contamination field.
Once per round, when hit, gain +2 Evasion until end of your next turn. The armor reacts to threats by hardening.
At the start of each encounter, gain temporary HP equal to your Grit bonus. The organism generates a protective buffer. Temp HP doesn't stack between encounters.
When you take damage, heal 1 HP. Doesn't trigger on damage-over-time (Bleed, Poison) — only direct hits. The mesh feeds on kinetic energy.
Once per encounter, when hit by an attack, you can phase — the attack passes through you harmlessly. +2 Toxicity.
Immune to forced movement (knockback, push, drag, teleportation by enemies). You are fixed in local spacetime. +1 Toxicity per encounter.
Enemies within Adjacent range deal -1 damage per die against all targets (not just you). Localized entropy dampens kinetic energy. +1 Toxicity per round active.
Store up to 3 Toxicity in the armor instead of your body. Can discharge stored Toxicity as a free action (transfers back to you). Useful for Channelers managing casting costs.
At the start of combat, you see enemy HP ranges (full/above half/below half/critical) and active conditions on all enemies within Medium range. Requires neural jack.
Cannot be surprised. You always act in the first round of combat, even in ambushes. Requires neural jack.
You always know your exact HP, Toxicity percentage, and active conditions numerically. No guessing. Also displays the same for allies within Close range. Requires neural jack.
All allies with Ally Link can communicate silently (subvocal comms) and share targeting data. +1 accuracy when two or more linked allies attack the same target. Requires neural jack.

content.text: Shields only accept Mechanical mods (you can't graft a living organism onto a buckler — well, you probably shouldn't).

rows: Shield Bash attack: d8 accuracy (Chrome), 1d6 damage, 1 AP. Gives shields an offensive option.
+1 Evasion vs Magic attacks. Reflects some dimensional energy.
First hit per encounter absorbed completely (0 damage). Must repair between encounters (25 cr).
Plant the shield (1 AP). While planted, provides Heavy Cover (+2 Evasion) to you and one ally behind you. You can't move while planted. Pull it up for 1 AP.

content.text: A dedicated crafter is a crew force multiplier. They save the crew money on ammo, install mods without shop fees, maintain equipment, and can build things nobody sells. The crafter doesn't need to swing a weapon well — their contribution is making everyone else's weapons swing better.
Crafting is a gated skill — you cannot attempt it without at least T1 training. It uses Interface as its stat.

rows: Craft basic ammunition. Repair damaged equipment. Identify materials and their uses.

Install Mechanical, Chemical, and Neural mods. Craft special ammunition (AP, Incendiary, Rift-Tipped). Create basic consumables (Med Patches, Flares). Salvage mods from destroyed equipment (50% recovery chance).

Install Biological and Rift mods. Craft advanced consumables (Combat Stims, Scrubbers). Design custom mods (work with GM). Create gear from raw rift materials (Bone Edge weapons, Living Armor). Salvage at 75% recovery chance.

Create unique gear (one-of-a-kind weapons/armor with custom properties). Install any mod with auto-success (no check). Reverse-engineer enemy equipment. Create experimental mods that exceed normal parameters (GM collaboration).

content.text: Crafting happens during downtime (between missions). Each crafting action costs 1 downtime activity unless noted.

rows: Restore damaged gear to full function. Costs 25% of gear's value in materials.
Produce charges worth a credit budget (see ammo crafting table in Equipment).
On failure, mod not installed. No damage.
On failure, mod consumed. Must buy another.
On failure, mod not installed. No damage.
Create one consumable. Costs 50% of retail in materials.
Produce special charges (AP, Incendiary, Rift-Tipped) at 60% of retail materials cost.
On failure, mod consumed. 10% chance of 1d6 damage to gear.
On failure, mod consumed. +1d6 Toxicity to crafter.
Recover a mod from destroyed/discarded gear. T2: 50% success. T3: 75%.
Create a piece of gear from raw rift materials. Requires appropriate T3 materials. Result is unique — GM and player collaborate on stats.
Design a new mod not on the standard list. GM approval required.
Study enemy equipment. Learn its properties and gain schematics to reproduce similar mods.

content.text: Crafting requires materials harvested from rift expeditions or purchased from suppliers.

rows: Basic rift harvests, scrap metal, standard chemicals
Targeted harvests, specific creature parts, refined chemicals
Chemical mods, Neural mods, Biological mods (basic), special ammo
Elite creature parts, dimensional anomaly residue, rift crystals
Biological mods (advanced), Rift mods, building from scratch
Boss drops, unique dimensional materials, experimental compounds
Custom mods, unique gear, experimental projects

content.text: Material units are abstract. One unit of T2 Bio materials might be a Bloom Spitter's toxin gland, a Stalker's nerve cluster, or a vial of refined Char residue. The GM determines what's available based on what the crew harvests.
Why have a crafter on the crew?

A T2 crafter saves the crew roughly 200-500 cr per downtime through installation fees, discounted ammo, and cheaper repairs. A T3 crafter saves more AND unlocks mods nobody else can access. Over a campaign, the crafter pays for their own training many times over.

rows: Suppressor (300 cr, Mechanical) — remain hidden after firing
Reaction Sights (300 cr, Mechanical) — Overwatch at weapon AP, not +1
Predictive Aim (350 cr, Neural) — +1 acc vs targets that moved

Fires from stealth without revealing position. Overwatches at 5 AP instead of 6 (now possible within a single turn). +3 total accuracy vs stationary targets at range (+2 base conditional + 1 Predictive for movers). The definitive sniper platform.
Balanced Haft (150 cr, Mechanical) — AP cost reduced to 3
Corrosive Treatment (250 cr, Chemical, permanent) — Corrode 1 on hit

3 AP attacks that strip armor on every hit. At 3 AP, you can swing + move, or swing + use item. The Corrode stacking means every hit makes the NEXT hit deadlier. Against an Armor 6 target, three hits = Corrode 3 = effective Armor 3.
Living Armor (600 cr, Biological, permanent) — grappled enemies take 1d6/turn, self-repairing
Symbiotic Shell (700 cr, Biological, permanent) — temp HP = Grit bonus per encounter
Spore Membrane (400 cr, Biological, permanent) — melee attackers gain +1 Toxicity

A walking biohazard fortress. Anything that grabs you takes 1d6/turn. Anything that hits you in melee risks +1 Toxicity. You start each fight with bonus HP. The armor repairs its own Corrode damage. Combined with Leech augments, you're a nightmare to engage in melee.
Threat HUD (250 cr, Neural) — see all enemy HP/conditions
Ally Link (300 cr, Neural) — silent comms, +1 acc when focus-firing
Auto-Injector Mount (200 cr, Mechanical) — auto Med Patch at 25% HP
Burst Pistol with Targeting Link (300 cr, Neural)

Sees the entire battlefield state. Coordinates the crew through subvocal comms. When two linked allies attack the same target, +1 accuracy for both. Auto-heals when low. The Negotiator doesn't need to do damage — they make everyone else's damage count more.
Quick Mag, Reflex Sights, Venom Coating
Precision Sights + Serrated Edge, Balanced Haft + Corrosive Treatment
Stabilizer + Reaction Sights + Phase Rounds, Balanced Haft + Bone Edge

content.text: "Vehicle operation within corporate zones requires a valid transit license (Class C minimum). Vehicle operation within rift zones requires a Class R endorsement, hazard insurance, and a notarized acknowledgment that your insurer will not cover dimensional displacement of the vehicle or its contents. Unlicensed operation is punishable by asset seizure. Your vehicle is an asset. So are you."
